thread.title: China talks expected by week's end
thread.title_full: China talks expected by week's end | Business Spectator

author: AAP
title: China talks expected by week's end
text:
Talks between the government and Labor on passing the China free trade agreement are expected to start this week.
Labor has unveiled the changes it wants to see to ensure Australian workers are protected before the enabling laws are passed.
But it will not seek the renegotiation of the agreement itself.
Shadow trade minister Penny Wong said Labor understands the many economic benefits of the agreement passing the parliament by the end of the year.
But Senator Wong hopes Trade Minister Andrew Robb will be open to the opposition's proposals.
The Labor plan calls for laws to be changed to require companies involved in projects valued at more than $150 million and using new investment facilitation arrangements to advertise jobs locally before turning to overseas workers.
The minimum base rate of pay for 457 visa workers would rise to $57,000 a year and be indexed.
And 457 visa holders in trades such as electrical work and plumbing would need to get a licence or registration within 60 days of arriving in Australia.
Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull says the government will negotiate in good faith.
